summary: I am an Asphalt Pavement Materials Engineer. I have 18 years research experience with a specific focus on asphalt materials, recycling technologies for asphalt pavement, self-healing systems for asphalt pavements and sustainable bio-based construction materials. I hold BEng and MPhil in Mechanical Engineering from Technological University Dublin (formaly known as Dublin Institute of Technology) and PhD in Civil/Mechanical Engineering from University College Dublin. I have a solid publication record and to date have been awarded > €1M in research funding and €67,000 in funding for teaching and laboratory activities. Between January 2015 and December 2016 I held a Marie Curie IEF Fellowship hosted by TU Delft. After returning to Ireland in January 2017 I have taken a post at Technological University Dublin as Strategic Research Proposal Coordinator within university Research, Enterprise and Innovation Department. I was responsible for promotion of research within the university and assisting academics with their national and international research funding applications. In 2019 I was awarded an Enterprise Ireland Commercialisation Funding to enable the commercialisation of a self-healing system for asphalt pavements. Project run from November 2019 until March 2021. The commercialisation is currently paused while technology validation is in the progress. In 2020 I was  awarded a MSCA Individual Fellowship for a project entitled: ‘Advanced Solutions for Asphalt Pavements (ASAP)’, with TNO as host institution and TU Delft as a partner. Project started on 1st September 2021 and will run until September 2023. ASAP project focuses on investigation and design of an alternative (bio) asphalt binder rejuvenator. I have supervised undergraduate, Masters and PhD research projects in TU Delft and have contributed to PhD supervision in UCD and TU Delft. My long term career goal is to become an entrepreneur and to introduce innovative and disruptive technology to the asphalt pavement industry.​

treasury_media.title: Bio-Binder—Innovative Asphalt Technology
treasury_media.description: A special issue, “Advances in Asphalt Pavement Technologies and Practices” aims to curate advanced/novel work in Asphalt Pavement design, construction and maintenance. The articles presented in this issue present work on sustainable asphalt pavement construction practices such as: recycling aged asphalt procedures, biological materials in asphalt mix design and Life Cycle Analysis of novel road design, construction and maintenance procedures..

treasury_media.title: A Novel Self-healing system: Towards a Sustainable Porous Asphalt
treasury_media.description: Self-healing asphalt, aimed to produce a sustainable asphalt pavement using green technology, has been studied in the past two decades. Technologies including encapsulated rejuvenator and induction heating have been proposed, demonstrated in the...

treasury_media.title: Are potholes about to become a thing of the past?
treasury_media.description: New technology may provide a resolution to how potholes and cracks causes accidents and congestion on our roads.

profile_positions.description: As an Associate Research Fellow at Delft University of Technology Microlab I am working together with Professor Erik Schlangen on development of novel self healing technology for asphalt pavements and Prof. Mark van Mark van Loosdrecht  TU Delft Env. Biotechnology on development of microalgae processing/oil extraction for use in development of bio-rejuvenator for aged bitumen. This work is carried out as part of the ASAP project.
profile_positions.title: Associate Research Fellow

profile_positions.description:
This Marie Curie Research Fellowship project is entitled: “Self Healing Asphalt for Road Pavements (SHARP).” The main focus the SHARP project is development of a self-healing technology for design and maintenance of the asphalt pavements. The SHARP project aims to develop a unique self-healing technology for asphalt pavements, whereby the encapsulated rejuvenator within the asphalt mix is used as the healing catalyst. Researchers at TU Delft have pioneered this technology by successfully developing a rejuvenator encapsulation method that thermally and mechanically survives the asphalt production process. Despite progress to date, the functionality of this self-healing technology remains unknown and as a result, self-healing technology is not accepted as standard within the road industry. The SHARP project builds on the TU Delft research to translate self-healing technology for asphalt pavements from theory into practice. 
The project has five key objectives, to:
i) select the most suitable, commercially available, healing agent, with emphasis on ecologically friendly ‘green’ rejuvenators,
ii) develop various encapsulation techniques combined with different capsule release techniques,
iii) develop a numerical model for simulating the release of healing agent from the capsule and its diffusion into binder in order to optimise the size, amount and distribution of the capsule,
iv) design an asphalt mix containing encapsulated healing agent and investigate its mechanical properties and
v) plan the transfer of technology from laboratory to field testing.

SHARP project website: http://atabakovic.wix.com/sharp01

profile_positions.description: The Advanced Solutions for Asphalt Pavements (ASAP) project involves the development of a unique road paving technology which will use a bio-bitumen rejuvenator to rejuvenate aged asphalt bitumen.  This technology will help to extend lifespan of  asphalt pavements (roads) and will reduce the  environmental and economic impact of roads and road maintenance processes. Recycling and self-healing processes will replace fossil fuel dependent technology.
profile_positions.title: Marie Sklodowska Curie Individual Research Fellow

profile_positions.description: Self-healing Asphalt (HealRoad) is an Enterprise Ireland funded research project which seeks to commercialise self-healing systems for asphalt pavements - roads.
profile_positions.title: Research Manager - Self-healing Asphalt (HealRoad) Project

profile_positions.description: As a Strategic Research Proposal Coordinator at Dublin Institute of Technology I am responsible for strategic support and coordination of pre-award research proposals planning and development and in general promotion research across the TU Dublin.
profile_positions.title: Strategic Research Proposal Coordinator

profile_positions.description:
As a Postdoctoral Researcher Fellow my key responsibilities were: 
•	To conduct and manage two CEDR research projects. Characterisation of Advanced Cold-recycled Bitumen Stabilised Pavement Solutions (CoRePaSol) – this project focuses on investigation of Cold Recycled Asphalt mix performance and Effects on Availability of Road Network (EARN) – this project focuses on investigation of Warm Recycled Asphalt mix performance. The work involved:
-	Communicating with PI and International project partners about projects progress,
-	Dissemination of results,
-	Conducting laboratory testing,
-	Organising and attending onsite testing and material test sample collection, such as: paving, coring and measurement of ride quality.  
•	Supervise undergraduate research projects in the UCD Highway Laboratory. This involved assisting students with the laboratory aspects of their work, helping them to organise their experimental programme, troubleshoot, collect and interpret their data and report. 
•	Management of the UCD Highway Laboratory. This involved maintenance of the testing equipment and work organisation in the laboratory. 
•	Preparation of tutorial sheets for the Structural Engineering module as part of the UCD Civil Engineering Course.
•	I was also internal examiner on the Water and Highway Engineering module as a part of the UCD Civil Engineering course.
profile_positions.title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow

profile_positions.description:
As a Consulting Researcher Engineer, I worked on a piece of consultancy work for an industrial partner (Dublin Aviation Authority). My specific responsibilities were as follows:
To develop a Finite Element (FE) model for the simulation of runway pavement behaviour using MSC Nastran Finite Element Software.
To conduct an intensive laboratory analysis (ITSM) of bituminous materials in order to obtain the material parameters for use in the FE model.
To communicate results back to the Industrial partner.
To supervise an ME Structural Engineering with Architecture 4th year research project. This entailed: advising student on numerical modeling and laboratory aspects of her work.
profile_positions.title: Researcher Engineer

profile_positions.description:
As a postdoctoral researcher in UCD my key responsibility was the management and further development of a research programme within the Transport Laboratory. This included: developing research ideas, investigating funding possibilities and developing industrial and inter-institutional collaborations. I also coordinated the preparation and submission of number of research funding proposals to the EU (7th Framework funding), National Roads Authority (NRA) and Enterprise Ireland. I was responsible for every aspect of these proposals including developing research consortia, compiling literature reviews, budget planning and coordinating information sharing between industrial and academic project partners.

I also co-supervised two PhD projects, one MSc project and several undergraduate final year projects annually. My role was to assist students with laboratory aspects of their work, helping them to organise their experimental programme, troubleshooting, data collection and interpretation and reporting.

In terms of teaching in UCD, I have delivered several undergraduate lectures in the School of Civil, Structural and Environmental Engineering. I was also involved in a project which presented the laboratory components of the civil engineering course to students via a series of videos. The videos were made available to students via Blackboard (UCDs virtual learning environment) to facilitate their understanding of pavement design and management. I was responsible for every aspect of the project, including drafting and submitting the funding application (UCD seed funding), writing the video scripts, recording the videos and voice overs, editing the videos using final cut software, and finally, uploading the videos onto Blackboard.

Much of the academic administration dimension of the post has involved the co-ordination of an eight month work placement for fourth year students on the Structural Engineering with Architecture degree course.
profile_positions.title: Postdoctoral Researcher

profile_positions.description: As a Development Engineer in ESIL, I was responsible for the structural analysis of engineering components and mechanical systems. I led on a research project which involved the examination of the structural integrity of a crystal ball, which was displayed in Time Square, New York. Specifically, the project examined the structural integrity of the glass panels - manufactured by Waterford Crystal - when subjected to extreme weather conditions. The analysis was conducted using ABAQUS finite element software. I also designed laboratory programme for testing the structural integrity of the crystal panels and the effectiveness of its fastening system. The tests were conducted in the UCD Mechanical Engineering Laboratories.  Another project which I was involved in involved the design of a fastening system for a space shuttle ventilation box, research which was undertaken on behalf of the European Space Agency. My work as Development Engineer also involved preparation of contract proposals, report writing, team working and liaising with industrial clients.
profile_positions.title: Development Engineer
